awd_titl_txt: Remote Lab-Sharing Models for Additive Manufacturing Skills Training
awd_abstract_narration:
Additive manufacturing, which is also known as 3D printing, is transforming the nation's manufacturing industry. A diverse and highly-skilled workforce is needed to support the economic growth in this area of manufacturing. To help address his need, Mohawk Valley Community College will partner with two colleges to develop a new training model for manufacturing technicians. These partners will develop courses that cover the most advanced technologies in this field, including metal 3D printing. The project team will partner with local industries to ensure that the courses contain the knowledge and skills desired for the workforce. The courses will include the use of remotely-shared 3D printing equipment for student design projects. The remote lab equipment will represent a model for colleges across the country to prepare students with the necessary skills, even if the colleges have limited budgets to purchase their own equipment. This model will reduce cost barriers for institutions and help increase the number of technicians that can be trained. The training model will provide options for current workers who want to upgrade their skills. The project will also create introductory courses for secondary school students, who will also be able to use the remotely-shared 3D printing equipment.

This project seeks to increase the number of skilled technicians in additive manufacturing design processes, with a special focus on metal 3D printing. The goals include: the development of a one-semester, 18-credit curriculum comprised of five courses that cover modeling, materials, and additive manufacturing topics; the development of a remote lab-sharing model for the curriculum that will be tested with the partner institutions, Finger Lakes Community College and Western Technical College; and research on the efficacy of the curriculum on student outcomes when used in local-lab versus remote-lab learning environments. Students at the partnering institutions will be able to remotely access the lab equipment to print prototypes, which will then be shipped back to their campuses. The curriculum will be designed for either seamless integration into existing two-year engineering technology programs or as a standalone microcredential option for incumbent workers. Dual-credit high school courses and mini modules for existing high school courses will also be developed and implemented. An emphasis of this project will be on engaging and recruiting students from underrepresented populations to promote their interest in manufacturing careers and broaden participation in the technician workforce. Course materials, project results, and best practices will be widely disseminated to encourage the adoption or adaptation of the approach by other colleges and institutions across the country.  This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Title: Remote Lab Models for the Additive Manufacturing Workforce

 

Project Overview:

The 'Remote Lab Models for the Additive Manufacturing Workforce' project aimed to address the evolving needs of the additive manufacturing industry by establishing a 15-credit program. This program was designed to equip graduates with the necessary knowledge and education to thrive in the dynamic field of additive manufacturing. The project was supported by an industrial advisory board comprised of 11 local business professionals actively engaged in additive manufacturing. Their insights were crucial in shaping the program's curriculum and learning outcomes.

 

Key Achievements:

 

Industrial Advisory Board Insights: The project engaged an industrial advisory board, consisting of local business professionals, to provide invaluable insights into the expected knowledge and skills of graduates. Through meetings and discussions, the advisory board contributed to the formulation of student learning outcomes that were aligned with industry needs.

 

Development of Additive Manufacturing Technician Micro-Credential Program: Leveraging the insights gained from the industrial advisory board, the project successfully developed a 15-credit Additive Manufacturing Technician Micro-Credential program. This program is designed to prepare students for careers in additive manufacturing and related industries.

 

Shared-Services Partnership Field Test: The project conducted a field test of a shared-services partnership between Mohawk Valley and Finger Lakes Community College. The objective was to evaluate the effectiveness of a remote shared model in providing additive manufacturing services to diverse locations and student populations. The tests demonstrated the feasibility of the remote shared services model for external institutions.

 

Community and High-School Outreach: The project team actively engaged in providing tours and conducting high-school outreach workshops to promote additive manufacturing awareness. Over the project's duration, the MVCC Fab Lab hosted more than 2,100 individuals from over 100 group events, enriching the understanding of additive manufacturing among diverse audiences.

 

Future Outlook:

The project's achievements have laid the foundation for the Additive Manufacturing Technician Micro-Credential program. As SUNY's program change approval process nears completion, the program is poised to offer valuable education and training opportunities for individuals seeking to excel in the additive manufacturing industry. Additionally, the success of the shared-services partnership and outreach efforts underscore the potential for expanded collaboration and engagement with external institutions and the community.

 

Conclusion:

The 'Remote Lab Models for the Additive Manufacturing Workforce' project has successfully achieved its goals of addressing industry needs, fostering collaboration, and promoting additive manufacturing awareness. The developed educational program and demonstrated models of shared services will strive to continue a lasting impact on the workforce and educational landscape within the additive manufacturing sector.

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2023
Modified by: Nathan C Roscup
